title: How does a person make a real personal change? - Quora

response.answer_text: It's never as easy as flicking on a light switch. We're creatures of habit, an thus it is even said that from the time we wake in the morning, till when we sleep, almost everything we do is carried out in a routine/habitual way (when we brush our teeth, how we commute to work, what we choose to do on weekend/days off- you get the point). To make any real/lasting change we must change our habits. Staying the same is a habit, changing and trying new things is a habit, and one can develop it- that's where you start. Speaking from experience, before I made any lasting changes I had to build up to it, or rather, become a person who had the will power to make a change and the ability to maintain it. Start by changing little things, and practice sustaining the new habit. It could be as simple as adding extra veggies to your meals, waking up 15minutes earlier than usual, or taking showers instead of baths(start with things that require less will power)… point is to get into the habit of doing things differently. Soon overtime, you will notice how changing these many little things have changed you as a person. At this point, one usually has the momentum and ability to take on the desired change. And be easy on yourself, if you notice you’re finding it challenging at first. The fact that your trying says alot.

In order to bring about a change, you’ve got to go within yourself and find your reason(s) to change; that’s what it all boils down to. When your reasons are strong enough you’ll find a way to make it happen, else you’ll find 1001 excuses not to. Often, a person will feel scared to bring about a personal change because it becomes a part of who they are. "The worst part about anything that’s self destructive is that it’s so intimate. You become so close with your addictions and illnesses that leaving them behind is like killing the part of yourself that taught you how to survive." -Lacey L. I’m assuming it’s something self destructive, ergo the decision to change it. You haven’t mentioned what it is that you want to change, and as far as a general approach is concerned, I think Kirke has given you the best way to go about it. If you’d like to discuss the specifics, don’t hold back from messaging me. Cheers.

ANTHONY ROBBINS (A life coach) says that a human being only changes for 2 reasons. Pursuit of pleasure or avoidance of pain. I believe he is right. Either way, change is uncomfortable when it begins but with a true desire to change, it can be done. I had character defects and qualities in myself that I did not find admirable. I wanted to change them but, like you, did not know where to start. So I started with education and information. I looked for people, places and things that were like minded. Meetings, therapy, sponsors or good friends that had already done it and could show me how. Using a combination of education and journaling for self evaluation and recognition I learned how to identify the behaviors I wanted to change. Once I could identify them I could then trace them back to what and where they started. When I learned that I constructed the cage and why it was easy to discard them but it took practice as I learned what to do to adjust the behavior in the moment. It's not easy. It takes practice. It took a lot of practice because I had lived a whole lifetime being one way. To be another was just weird at the start. I practiced over and over until some of the new behaviors became 2nd nature. Then I changed my look. Nothing to wild but just enough for me to feel good and better and different. I hope this helps. Educate, identify, evaluate, change it with repetition and practice.

It's simple and clear: they have to really WANT TO CHANGE. Once the desire to change has been agreed upon, then the skies are the limits. To reach this point, you would likely have to really dislike or even hate aspects of your personality that your heart knows need changing. After the determination to change has won you over, you must find the knowledge to do so.

There is no secret to change. “Real” personal change is a process. The process is a sequence of steps. Study the biology of fruit trees. Then study personal transformation. A person who makes real change will under go similar inner and outer nourishment processes to attain the desired change. Many will say that change is an accumulation of habits. Some will say that change is stepping out of comfort zones. Others will say that change is a state-of-mind. A few will say that change is a constant ratio between who you are to become from who you are today.
